articles.headline: Rev. Will D. Campbell, Maverick Minister in Civil Rights Era, Dies at 88
articles.snippet: Mr. Campbell, a rare white cleric with an extensive field record as a civil rights activist, also wrote  books that explored the human costs of racism.
articles.abstract: Mr. Campbell, a rare white cleric with an extensive field record as a civil rights activist, also wrote  books that explored the human costs of racism.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Will D. Campbell, a renegade preacher and author who joined the civil rights struggle in the 1950s, quit organized religion and fought injustice with nonviolent protests and a storyteller’s arsenal of autobiographical tales and fictional histories, died on Monday night in Nashville. He was 88.

articles.headline: Chrysler Rejects Regulator’s Request to Recall Jeeps
articles.snippet: The company said it disagreed that 2.7 million Jeep models posed a danger of fire in rear-impact accidents.
articles.abstract: The company said it disagreed that 2.7 million Jeep models posed a danger of fire in rear-impact accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In an escalating confrontation with regulators, Chrysler said on Tuesday that it would not recall 2.7 million Jeeps that the government contends are defective and prone to fires in the event of rear-impact collisions.

articles.headline: From Lottery to Oligopoly in Wireless Spectrum
articles.snippet: In auctioning off the public airwaves, the government’s thirst for revenue competes with the goal of fostering competition.
articles.abstract: In auctioning off the public airwaves, the government’s thirst for revenue competes with the goal of fostering competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all its sleek iThing patina today, the origins of the wireless communications revolution had a decidedly Wild West feel.

articles.headline: In China, an Empire Built by Aping Apple
articles.snippet: Led by Lei Jun, Xiaomi sold $2 billion in handsets in China last year, and he has carefully cultivated an image in the Steve Jobs mold.
articles.abstract: Led by Lei Jun, Xiaomi sold $2 billion in handsets in China last year, and he has carefully cultivated an image in the Steve Jobs mold.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China is notorious for its knockoffs. But now comes a knockoff of one of the gods of American ingenuity: Steven P. Jobs.

articles.headline: Syrian Rebels Meet Setbacks on a New Front
articles.snippet: The rebels have been pulled between the limits of a lightly equipped guerrilla force and their urge to fight with the battlefield weight of an army.
articles.abstract: The rebels have been pulled between the limits of a lightly equipped guerrilla force and their urge to fight with the battlefield weight of an army.
articles.lead_paragraph: IBLIL, Syria — The airstrikes resumed at 7:30 a.m., beginning with a rolling series of explosions in the village of Zoghba. An extended roar shook the northern Hama Plain.

articles.headline: A County in Alabama Strikes a Bankruptcy Deal
articles.snippet: Jefferson County reached an agreement to refinance most of the debt that led to its $4.2 billion municipal bankruptcy, the largest such filing in United States history.
articles.abstract: Jefferson County reached an agreement to refinance most of the debt that led to its $4.2 billion municipal bankruptcy, the largest such filing in United States history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jefferson County, Ala., took a big step toward resolving its historic bankruptcy case on Tuesday, saying it had reached an agreement to refinance most of the debt at the heart of its financial breakdown.

articles.headline: As Vandals Deface U.S. Parks, Some Point to Online Show-Offs
articles.snippet: Park personnel say there is reason to believe that a spike in vandalism and graffiti that has found its way into the wilderness coincides with the rise of social media.
articles.abstract: Park personnel say there is reason to believe that a spike in vandalism and graffiti that has found its way into the wilderness coincides with the rise of social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK, Ariz. — When Steve Bolyard checked out a report of black paint on some of the park’s majestic saguaros — cactuses whose towering bodies and upraised arms are as emblematic of the American West as red-rock buttes and skittering tumbleweeds — he did not expect to see ganglike calligraphy covering more of them than he could easily count.

articles.headline: Park Defender Helped Set Off Turkey’s Crisis
articles.snippet: The government’s plans to convert a park in Istanbul into a mall designed like an Ottoman-era army barracks sparked protests that exposed a fault line in Turkey.
articles.abstract: The government’s plans to convert a park in Istanbul into a mall designed like an Ottoman-era army barracks sparked protests that exposed a fault line in Turkey.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — It was just before midnight a week ago Monday when three friends saw the bulldozer approaching the edge of the park.

articles.headline: U.S.-China Meeting’s Aim: Personal Diplomacy
articles.snippet: An upcoming visit between President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China, aimed at nurturing a high-level friendship, will be less scripted than such meetings usually are.
articles.abstract: An upcoming visit between President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China, aimed at nurturing a high-level friendship, will be less scripted than such meetings usually are.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Tom Donilon, President Obama’s national security adviser, met with President Xi Jinping in Beijing last week to discuss his coming visit to the United States, China’s newly minted leader told him he wanted a conversation with Mr. Obama that did not involve diplomatic talking points. As if to underscore the message, he ignored the notes sitting in front of him.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Bloomberg Begins Fund to Invest in Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Bloomberg Beta is the first time that Bloomberg L.P. will reap profits from investments in some of the technology companies that its news operation covers.
articles.abstract: Bloomberg Beta is the first time that Bloomberg L.P. will reap profits from investments in some of the technology companies that its news operation covers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the increasingly clubby world of Silicon Valley, some might say it was almost inevitable that Bloomberg L.P., the parent of Bloomberg News, would start its own venture capital firm to invest in start-ups, including some that its technology reporters write about.

articles.headline: In Syrian Victory, Hezbollah Risks Broader Fight
articles.snippet: Hezbollah’s role has further antagonized sectarian divisions in Syria and beyond, creating new risks for both the Syrian government and the militia even in their moment of victory.
articles.abstract: Hezbollah’s role has further antagonized sectarian divisions in Syria and beyond, creating new risks for both the Syrian government and the militia even in their moment of victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the final days the outgunned Syrian rebels, deprived of reinforcements, ammunition and sleep, were surviving on olives and canned beans. They were hiding in the concrete shells of destroyed houses and underground tunnels near the besieged rebel stronghold of Qusayr, unable to help their trapped colleagues and civilians dying of treatable wounds, as Syrian government forces and their Hezbollah allies from Lebanon assaulted the town by land and air.
